question: Roger goes to the store to buy some coffee.  The normal brand of coffee he buys cost $5 per pound.  He had to buy a more expensive brand that cost 20% more since his favorite brand was sold out.  He decides to buy a week's worth of coffee and he uses 1 pound of coffee per day.  He also decided to buy himself a donut for $2.  How much did everything cost?
answer:
The coffee he bought was 5*.2=$<<5*.2=1>>1 more expensive per pound than what he normally buys
So it cost 5+1=$<<5+1=6>>6 per pound
He goes through 1*7=<<1*7=7>>7 pounds of coffee a week
So he paid 6*7=$<<6*7=42>>42 on coffee
That means his total bill was 42+2=$<<42+2=44>>44
#### 44
question_annotated:
{name,Roger} goes to the store to buy some {item,coffee}. The normal brand of {item,coffee} he buys costs {cur,$}{price,5} per {unit,pound}. He has to buy a more expensive brand that costs {percent,20}% more since his favorite brand was sold out. He decides to buy a week's worth of {item,coffee} and he uses {usage,1} {unit,pound}s of {item,coffee} per day. The store has a {p,50}% discount on {item,coffee} which applies only up to {limit,10} {unit,pound}s; any additional {item,coffee} is sold at the regular price. {name,Roger} also decides to buy himself a {extra_item,donut} for {cur,$}{extra_price,2}. How much does {name,Roger} have to pay?

- item = sample(['tea', 'sugar', 'flour', 'rice'])

- $price = range(3, 17)
- $percent = range(10, 50, 5)
- $usage = range(2, 4)
- $extra_price = range(1, 5)
- $p = range(5, 51, 5)
- $limit = range(10, 21, 10)

#conditions:
- is_int(price * percent / 100)
- usage * 7 > limit
- is_int((limit * (price+price*percent//100) * (1-p/100)))
